James P. Sullivan (Sulley).Action: Responds humorously and playfully to Mike’s teasing wake-up call, showing tolerance and friendly interaction.
Engages in physical exercise and play-acts intimidating poses despite being teased, indicating good-natured and sincere behavior.
Wakes up late and is found snoring loudly, needing Mike to forcibly wake him up.
Responds to Mike's wake-up call with physical exercise and roaring to assert his scariness despite initial reluctance.
Plays along energetically with Mike's playful scaring exercises, showing engagement and good-natured cooperation.
Strains to move heavy furniture while Mike encourages him, demonstrating diligence and willingness to support teamwork.
Brushes his teeth while hanging out with Mike, showing a casual friendly interaction and mutual comfort.
Slips and falls but laughs it off to watch the commercial with Mike, displaying sincerity and a friendly, relaxed demeanor.
Cheerfully points out himself on a company commercial and participates with enthusiasm, showing pride in his work and camaraderie with Mike.
Successfully scares a child on factory work floor, demonstrating skill as a top scarer.
Stands confidently on camera representing Monsters, Inc. to workers and public, showing confidence and capability.
Leans in to roar through a door efficiently during work, indicating focus and professionalism.
Consoles Mike when he is excited about being on TV.
Jokes with Mike about being jealous since fourth grade, maintaining friendly banter.
Politely acknowledges greeting from tiny monster wife, showing social politeness.
Prevents Mike from impulsively using a new shiny convertible, opting instead to walk due to scream shortage.
Turns off the TV upon seeing a promotional commercial about Monsters, Inc., indicating focus rather than distraction.
Consoles Mike when Mike is excited about being on TV, showing emotional intelligence but no direct indication of competence in skill or capability.
Recognizes the potential negative implication of Mike’s TV appearance by joking 'Like on Monsters’ Most Wanted?', showing situational awareness.
Refuses to get into a shiny convertible and instead drags Mike away, prioritizing practical concerns over superficial benefits.
States 'there’s a scream shortage. We're walking...' indicating his understanding of the current work environment and making a deliberate choice.
Greets monster kids warmly with 'Hey, morning kids. How're you doing?'
Dismisses Mike's explanation about the car by saying 'Not really.' and 'Give it a rest, will ya, butterball?'
Persistently chooses to walk despite opposition and inconvenience, promoting exercise and responsible behavior.
Dismisses Mike's reasoning about the car without engagement, showing some impatience or dismissal.
Greeted Tony and Ted cheerfully and engaged in friendly banter, showing politeness and warmth.
Thanked Tony after receiving fruit offered on the house, showing gratitude and friendliness.
Responded warmly to various coworkers greeting him in the lobby with cheerful and inclusive remarks.
Maintains friendly, confident interactions with coworkers, indicating good social skills and positive reputation.
Acknowledges nearing the all-time scare record and casually states he is 'just trying to make sure there’s enough scream to go around,' showing focus and confidence in his work.
Receives friendly recognition from multiple coworkers and has twelve 'Scarer of the Month' photos displayed, demonstrating proven competence and respect among peers.
Warmly greets coworkers Needleman and Smitty and tells them to call him Sulley, fostering friendliness.
Politely responds to Celia’s birthday wishes despite feeling uncomfortable, showing sincerity and tolerance.
Maintains focus despite distractions from colleagues.
Responds politely but somewhat awkwardly in social interaction with Celia.
Expresses happiness for Mike's success in romance.
Jokes with Mike about the reservation name, indicating friendly rapport.
Tells Randall to save his attitude for the scare floor, calling out negativity calmly.
Calmly responds to Mike's excitement and thanks without showing jealousy or distraction.
Tells Randall to save his antics for the scare floor, showing confidence and assertiveness.
Does not intervene when Mike is surprised and startled by Randall's ambush in the locker room.
Extends hand and says 'Hey, may the best monster win' to a rival competitor Randall.
Cracks knuckles and shakes to keep loose before the competition begins, showing readiness and confidence.
Leads the SCARE TOTALS, indicating superior skill and effectiveness in scaring.
Exchanges a courteous sportsmanship gesture with rival Randall wishing 'may the best monster win', showing confidence and professionalism.
Rushes confidently through door to begin scaring shift, immediately starts accumulating scare totals.
Expresses feeling good and confident about performance during the shift.
Exits door promptly to check results and tally performance on jumbo-tron, showing awareness of progress.
Gives fans high fives and accepts their admiration graciously.
Responds humbly to praise by saying 'just doing my job'.
Emerges after Randall and quickly regains the top scare leader position with an impressive display, earning admiration and praise.
Casually cracks knuckles and says 'Slumber party' before moving confidently to scare and collect screams.
Responds modestly to praise, stating he's just doing his job, indicating confidence without arrogance.
Responds modestly and confidently to praise from Mr. Waternoose, showing self-assurance and professionalism.
Reassures Waternoose during a tough time, expressing loyalty and support.
Agrees to help train inexperienced new recruits without hesitation.
Playfully demonstrates the 'old Waternoose jump and growl' to amuse Waternoose.
Calmly reassures Waternoose that they will get through the rough time together.
Quickly understands Waternoose's criticism about new recruits being inexperienced.
Volunteers enthusiastically to help by giving a demonstration to new recruits.
Confidently performs an intimidating demonstration ('old Waternoose jump and growl') that startles Waternoose and earns his approval.
Responds supportively to Mike's enthusiasm about his romantic plans with simple affirmations and friendly banter.
Offers to share his odorant with Mike when asked, showing helpfulness and camaraderie.
Responds with mild dismissal 'Give me a break, Mike' when Mike jokes about romance, showing casual, friendly teasing rather than coldness.
Reflects confidently on his successful performance at work, anticipating breaking a scare record.
Plans to work out after work to maintain his physical conditioning and skill.
Engages casually in conversation without showing signs of confusion or hesitation.
Remembers and helps Mike with the details about the paperwork, showing attentiveness and cooperation.
Cautiously opens the active door and gently greets the little girl with a stage whisper, indicating care and sensitivity.
Remembers and correctly sorts the paperwork colors and their destinations despite initial confusion.
Identifies and clarifies the confusing term 'puce' when unsure.
Notices an active door that is out of place and investigates cautiously.
Picks up the little girl carefully, uses tongs to handle her gently, puts her back in her room, and carries her deep inside the room to keep her safe.
Panics and screams repeatedly upon encountering the little girl, loses composure, makes a mess in the process.
Attempts to hide or get rid of the kid’s belongings by flushing the toilet and stuffing a locker, indicating discomfort or unwillingness to deal with the situation calmly.
Panics and tries to get rid of the little girl by hiding her in a gym bag and running away.
Panic-strickenly runs away from the little girl, showing fear and lack of immediate control.
Cowers backed into a corner, indicating a moment of being overwhelmed and unsure what to do.
Finds a gym bag, quickly scoops up the little girl, and zips it closed to contain her, showing quick thinking and resourcefulness.
Attempts to return the child through the door but is trapped on the scare floor and must find a way to hide from Randall, showing situational awareness but limited options.
Successfully hides behind the door and avoids detection from Randall, displaying stealth and presence of mind under pressure.
After Randall leaves, Sulley watches the kid’s door vanish into the vault, realizing his plan to rid himself of the kid has failed, indicating acceptance of failure and need for new strategy.
Grabs the gym bag and runs toward the exit, acting decisively to remove the child from the area.
Presses his face to the window to listen in on Mike and Celia's conversation, then awkwardly interrupts their moment by appearing at their table and squeezing into the booth uninvited.
Tries to make conversation and orders food with Mike, attempting to engage despite Mike's irritation.
Presses his face up to the window excitedly when Mike mentions him; appears somewhat nervous and awkward when joining Mike and others at the table; interrupts Mike's romantic moment unintentionally.
Attempts to engage with Mike by bringing paperwork and trying to be helpful despite social awkwardness.
Frantically looks around for the missing bag and reacts strongly to the child's presence, showing concern and urgency.
Notices the MI duffle bag moving suspiciously and tries to investigate despite confusion, showing alertness to the situation.
Looks around frantically for the bag initially, indicating some momentary disorientation or lack of situational control.
Charges toward the bag despite stumbling into a waiter, showing initiative and urgency but also some clumsiness.
Tries to catch the human kid, playfully interacts, gently pushes her head down to keep her safe.
Grabs Mike and yanks him away from a confrontation to prevent trouble.
Tries to grab the kid who is playfully evading him, then accepts Mike's help to safely contain the kid in the takeout box.
Hesitantly pushes the kid's head into the box and shuts the lid, showing some uncertainty but still taking action to secure the situation.
Runs out quickly with Mike after securing the kid, abandoning the gym bag behind.
Grabs Mike and yanks him away from conflict with CDA agents, preventing escalation.
Wears protective gear (colanders, snorkel masks, oven mitts) when facing a dangerous unknown situation, indicating precaution and readiness.
Screams and scrambles for cover in response to the girl's appearance, showing fear and lack of immediate control.
Yanks shades closed to avoid detection from helicopters and retreats with Mike, demonstrating quick protective action and situational awareness.
Tosses the teddy bear to the frightened girl so she can have something comforting.
Insists that Mike give the teddy bear back to the girl despite Mike's objections.
Protects himself cautiously when approached by the girl, but remains gentle and tries to help.
Throws the bear to distract the girl and keep her calm, showing quick thinking.
Tells Mike to give the bear back to the girl to soothe her despite Mike's protests, demonstrating confident decision-making under pressure.
Protects himself with a garbage can lid when approached by the girl, showing cautiousness but also a reactive rather than fully confident stance.
Desperately tries to stop the girl from crying by offering a bear and dancing with it, even singing to soothe her.
Screams loudly and reacts fearfully when the girl touches his hand, causing her to start crying again.
Attempts to soothe the crying girl by offering the bear and then desperately dancing and singing to calm her down.
Screams when the girl accidentally touches his hand, which frightens her and causes her to cry again.
Gently shushes the little girl to maintain quiet, and acknowledges her mimicking with a smile.
Shows concern and self-reproach saying 'How could I do this? How could I be so stupid? This could destroy the company!'
Responds with disbelief to Mike's spoon tunnel plan, showing skepticism but not dismissiveness.
Appears deeply touched and surprised by the little girl’s drawing depicting them holding hands.
Calms the little girl by encouraging silence and interprets her gesture correctly.
Expresses self-doubt by calling himself 'stupid' and worries about destroying the company.
Shows disbelief and skepticism when Mike suggests digging a tunnel with spoons.
Unable to generate a viable plan to solve their problem and is stuck in disbelief.
Creates a trail of cereal to help the kid get comfortable and ready to sleep.
Lets the kid take over his bed despite initial reluctance.
Reassures the kid about the closet and shows empathy toward her fears.
Speaks to the kid somewhat impersonally, like talking to a dog.
Creates a trail of cereal and sets up a sleeping area to help the kid get comfortable and sleep.
Tries to reassure the kid by demonstrating the closet is empty and not scary.
Speaks gently and tries to comfort the kid patiently despite her anxiety.
Underestimates the kid’s lingering fear despite his efforts, as she remains anxious and frightened.
Sits with the scared kid until she falls asleep, attempts to soothe her with gentle gestures and humor.
Observes the kid sleeping peacefully and reflects that she doesn't look dangerous, showing empathy and reconsideration.
Suggests returning the kid back through her door to restore normalcy, showing responsibility and a desire to fix the situation without causing harm.
Patiently sits with the scared child until she falls asleep, using calm persistence and creativity (miming words) to soothe her.
Suggests putting the child back through her door to restore normalcy, showing practical problem-solving and logical thinking.
Resigns to sitting with the child rather than acting impulsively or forcing a solution, demonstrating self-control and emotional intelligence.
Does not immediately escalate or panic about the child being in their world, instead considering a calm and reasoned approach.
Turns to hide the kid behind his back when a fellow worker approaches, showing protective behavior.
Greets a fellow worker (Frank) cheerfully and casually.
Reassures Mike that 'Everything’s going to be okay.'
Repeatedly tells himself and Mike 'Don’t panic' and 'Just stay calm!', trying to comfort and stabilize the situation.
Keeps the child hidden behind his back as they approach the lobby, showing protective and cautious behavior.
Tries to reassure Mike and himself repeatedly by saying 'Don’t panic' and 'Everything’s going to be okay' despite evident danger.
Acts panic-stricken along with Mike when the little girl unexpectedly appears, indicating loss of composure under pressure.
Quickly sweeps the kid up into his arms when asked if the child is his relative.
Expresses concern that the kid can’t stay in the men’s locker room, showing protective behavior.
Quickly sweeps the kid up into his arms to protect her from Waternoose.
Attempts to deflect the question about the kid by making an uncertain excuse (my cousin’s... sister’s... daughter).
Expresses hesitation and tries to avoid the scare demonstration by saying 'today might be a little--'.
Shows concern for the kid's safety by objecting to leaving her in the men's locker room, despite Mike's dismissive attitude.
Flees the CDA agents with Mike without confronting or stopping them directly.
Plays along with the little girl's hide-and-seek game, laughs and expresses genuine amusement and appreciation of her cleverness.
Shows embarrassment and apologizes after accidentally invading the girl's privacy by trying to open the bathroom stall door.
Crawls playfully along the row of stalls, engaging in a playful hide-and-seek style interaction.
Comforts the whimpering girl by gently addressing her and showing concern.
Denies losing the kid initially but immediately attends to her when she appears.
Comforts the lost child promptly when she latches onto his arm, showing attentiveness and presence of mind.
Crawls playfully along bathroom stalls in a non-professional, casual manner while searching for the child.
Quickly locates the missing child demonstrating situational awareness and effective search skills.
Gives an unclear or evasive explanation to Mike when asked about the lost child, showing possible hesitation or uncertainty.
Awkwardly does his best to comfort the whimpering child while hiding from Randall.
Comforts the scared child awkwardly while hiding from Randall in a dangerous situation.
Hides effectively with Mike and the child to avoid detection by Randall.
Does not prevent Mike from slipping after Randall and Fungus exit.
Remains calm and encourages Mike not to panic despite the situation being bad.
Attempts to verify details about the girl’s door and correctly identifies the wrong door being used by Mike.
Leans down and interacts gently with the girl, showing confidence and skill in handling the situation.
Does not intervene directly when Mike steals a card key and seems reliant on Mike to manage key actions.
Slams the door shut on Boo's door without hesitation.
Decides to call the little girl 'Boo,' showing personal attachment.
Joins Mike in the playful rehearsal of the musical despite awkwardness.
Shows genuine panic and concern when Boo disappears.
Recognizes that the door they have is not Boo’s door and shows concern when Boo is missing, indicating situational awareness and responsibility.
Joins Mike Wazowski in improvising a musical scene to cover up being caught, showing quick thinking and adaptability.
Panics when Boo is missing, showing momentary lack of composure.
Decides to leave Boo behind, stating 'It'll be their problem, not ours! She’s out of our hair!'
Scans the room and moves away from Boo despite Mike’s pleas, showing avoidance of responsibility for Boo’s safety.
Quickly decides to leave the scene after Boo escapes, showing focus on priorities rather than panic.
Scans the room carefully while moving towards the exit, demonstrating alertness and situational awareness.
Turns corner and accidentally collides with Randall, indicating a slight lapse in spatial awareness or caution.
Appears nervous and hesitant when confronted by Randall, stammering and unable to give a clear response.
Runs down the hall searching for Boo, shows relief upon finding her, reacts with concern when Boo falls into the trash can, and willingly agrees to give an autograph to CDA agents.
Signs an autograph for the geeks with a friendly note 'From your scary friend... best wishes...'
Gasps and hurries after Boo’s eyestalk falls into the trash chute, showing concern for her safety
Watches horrified as Boo’s eyestalk and trash go through dangerous machinery, then faints from distress
Cradles Boo's garbage cube, showing emotional distress and care for her well-being.
Runs to Boo upon seeing her, expressing affectionate recognition.
Picks up Boo and hugs her tightly, expresses relief and concern for her safety.
Sternly warns Boo not to run away again but quickly returns to an affectionate tone.
Attempts to calm Boo when she squirms and runs off under a desk.
Picks up and hugs Boo tightly to protect her and shows concern for her safety.
Quickly tries to calm Boo after she squirms away and runs under a desk, indicating responsiveness and control in a tense situation.
At one point, seems momentarily confused about Mike having Boo’s door and asks for explanation rather than acting immediately.
Tries to calm Boo when she is scared.
Holds onto Boo tightly to protect her from danger.
Gently shushes Boo to help her stay quiet and calm.
Is cautious and distrustful of Randall, prioritizing Boo's safety over the rush to escape.
Avoids confrontation or risking Boo’s safety despite Mike's impatience and disagreement.
Carries Boo and follows Randall to protect her despite confusion and danger.
Encourages Boo positively by praising her ('Way to go!') when she accidentally opens the secret panel.
Reassures Boo when she whimpers ('It’s okay.').
Runs past Floor Manager without responding to question or greeting.
Discreetly backs into the darkness with Boo to avoid detection by Randall, showing situational awareness and protective behavior.
Does not immediately confront Randall or intervene directly while Mike is threatened by the Scream Extractor machine, indicating possible hesitation or caution.
Emerges quickly from the tool panel doorway with Mike and Boo and runs down the hall, taking immediate action in a tense situation.
Stops and turns back to help Mike and Boo instead of fleeing
Calls back to Mike to follow him with an idea, showing leadership and concern
Enters the simulator room abruptly holding Boo to intervene and explain the situation
Stops and turns back deliberately to come up with a plan, telling Mike to follow him because he has an idea.
Rushes into Waternoose's office holding Boo, interrupting the simulated tryout to raise urgent concerns.
Reluctantly complies with Waternoose's demand to roar despite discomfort, showing hesitation and concern.
Notices Boo’s fear after roaring and tries to comfort her, reaching out gently and speaking reassuringly.
Roars in a way that deliberately frightens Boo, following orders to impress recruits.
Reluctantly follows Waternoose's order to roar despite personal hesitation, producing a powerful and effective roar that impresses the recruits.
Tries to reason with Waternoose and shows hesitation about performing the staged roar, indicating some uncertainty or lack of confidence in the situation.
Recognizes Boo’s fear immediately after roaring and shows concern by seeking her out and trying to comfort her.
Approaches Boo gently and tries to calm her down despite her fear.
Shows visible remorse while watching Boo being taken by Waternoose.
Fails to immediately reassure Boo until Mike explains the situation; Boo remains frightened and cries.
Tries to calm Boo and reassure her despite her fear.
Unable to immediately gain Boo's trust due to his fearsome reputation.
Watches Boo being taken by Waternoose with visible remorse, showing emotional awareness but no direct intervention.
Tries in vain to catch Boo’s eye before being thrown through the door.
Panics and desperately tries to open the door to return to Boo.
Runs hands along the door frantically trying to activate it, showing care and concern.
Does not lash out in anger at Mike despite Mike’s criticism and physical aggression.
Sits silently at the mouth of the cave, staring at his hands and muttering to himself in anguish, showing vulnerability and self-reflection.
Does not respond to Yeti’s friendly offer and quietly broods, showing no outward friendliness or sociability in this scene.
Sits silently at the mouth of the cave, staring at his hands and muttering to himself in anguish, burying his face in his hands.
Immediately shows concern and urgency to find the kids' village and Boo, despite harsh conditions.
Punches the wall in frustration, potentially indicating stress but also deep emotional involvement.
Ignores Mike's angry protests and teasing while focused on rescuing Boo.
Immediately reacts with urgency to the mention of a village with kids, shifting focus to finding Boo, demonstrates quick decision making and goal orientation.
Punches wall in frustration, indicating a loss of temper but also leading to discovery of useful gear, showing ability to find solutions under stress.
Ignores Mike's protests and concerns, focused single-mindedly on the goal, which may suggest tunnel vision and lack of collaboration.
Apologizes to Mike for their predicament and expresses concern for Boo, indicating a plan to save her.
Silently pushes the makeshift toboggan past Mike without engaging directly when Mike pleads for consideration.
Does not respond to Mike’s rejection and leaves alone, showing a willingness to take responsibility despite isolation.
Builds a makeshift toboggan quickly and uses it to race down a dangerous mountainside, skillfully navigating the terrain with a lantern for light.
Acknowledges Mike’s feelings but insists on pursuing a risky plan to save Boo, showing decisiveness and prioritization.
Does not persuade Mike to come along, leading to Mike’s withdrawal and isolation even though teamwork might help, suggesting a possible lack of persuasive or collaborative skill in this moment.
Bursts through and tramples George Sanderson while rushing through the hallway, then apologizes briefly.
Sled crashes into a boulder and he tumbles down the mountain, lying motionless for a moment.
Quickly responds to the child's scream by looking toward the small Tibetan village, showing alertness and awareness.
Bursts through the hallway, trampling George Sanderson and ignoring others in his path, showing recklessness and lack of control.
Rushes in angrily to protect Boo from the Scream Extractor machine.
Apologizes sincerely to Boo ('I’m sorry, Boo').
Wrenches the machine from its moorings and throws it to stop the threat.
Frees Boo from the chair and picks her up to get her home.
Keeps holding Boo despite being attacked and punched from an unseen source.
Rips off the door to the secret passageway and runs through to rescue Boo.
Rushes in angrily at the right moment to save Boo from the Scream Extractor.
Wrenches the machine and throws it to pin Waternoose, Randall, and Fungus to the wall.
Picks Boo up and attempts to get her home safely, showing quick prioritization.
Fails to see where the invisible punches are coming from, gets repeatedly hit and knocked down.
Swings at Randall and misses, then is sent flying by Randall's tail whip.
Protects Boo and Mike by knocking out Randall after being attacked, despite being winded and choked.
Quickly responds to danger involving Boo and his friend, showing concern for their safety.
Carries both Boo and Mike to safety while under threat.
Expresses gladness that Mike came back, indicating appreciation and care.
Quickly responds to danger and urgency, prioritizing others' safety.
Does not engage in conflict or insults even when chased and pressured.
Presses red panic button to send Boo's door back to vault, interrupting normal process.
Runs to catch Boo’s door and rescues her before Randall can reach it.
Takes Boo in one hand and cushions her safety while grabbing onto the door, showing care and protection.
Recognizes threat of Randall intercepting Boo's door and presses the red panic button to return doors to vault, preventing Randall's plan.
Grabs Boo and a door to escape the Scare Floor despite chaos, showing quick thinking and decisiveness.
Runs toward another station to intercept doors, demonstrating active problem-solving and physical agility.
Acts confidently despite Mike's protest, indicating self-assurance in high-pressure situation.
Takes initiative to get Boo’s door and find a station despite danger.
Encourages Mike to make Boo laugh to help the situation.
Formulates and communicates a clear goal to retrieve Boo’s door and find a station despite the chaotic situation.
Maintains composure and directs others during the high-speed, dangerous door vault ride.
Visually tracks multiple doors and identifies Boo’s door among many, demonstrating situational awareness.
Realizes and vocalizes the dead-end and challenge of their position within the corridor of doors.
Suggests making Boo laugh as a potential solution impulsively without thorough explanation or apparent backup plan.
Commands to get the door open quickly as Randall approaches, showing prompt decision-making.
Quickly locates Boo’s door among thousands in the door vault and starts climbing toward it.
Reactively grabs Mike’s foot after his hand slips, saving him from falling thousands of feet.
Acknowledges sliding door mechanism after Mike prompts, showing adaptability.
Motions for Mike to jump into the door to escape Randall.
Looks for Mike after falling on him and immediately apologizes.
Encourages Mike by saying 'Great job buddy' after escaping Randall.
Quickly opens a door undergoing maintenance to provide an escape route for Mike, demonstrating resourcefulness and quick thinking under pressure.
Immediately urges Mike to get inside the door for safety, showing decisiveness and leadership in a stressful situation.
Accidentally falls onto Mike after both fall through the sideways door, indicating a minor lapse in spatial awareness or coordination.
Encourages Mike positively after escaping Randall (‘Great job buddy, we lost him!’) showing confidence and effective teamwork.
Fails to keep hold of Boo, who slips through his arms and disappears, which could suggest a momentary lapse in attention or control.
Struggles with Mike to hold onto a plunging door after Randall’s attack, showing perseverance despite dangerous circumstances.
Rushes to rescue Boo and pursues Randall despite danger.
Shows determination and courage to protect a child.
Commands Mike to open the door quickly and follows through by jumping out of the pile of doors to pursue Randall, showing initiative and leadership.
Balances precariously on the metal railing and times his leap perfectly onto a moving door, demonstrating physical skill and confidence.
Scans ahead for Randall and Boo, maintaining situational awareness during a dangerous chase.
Attempts a risky second jump onto a faster moving door but loses grip and almost falls, momentarily losing control.
Recovers balance quickly after almost falling and uses the door as a pendulum to swing forward into the room, regaining control and continuing the pursuit.
Despite being attacked and nearly thrown off the door, manages to hold on with one arm and later two fingers, preventing a fall.
Wrestles and subdues Randall after Boo helps distract him, demonstrating physical skill and control.
Initially caught off guard and overwhelmed by Randall’s attack and appears in danger of falling.
Shows relief and concern upon seeing Boo alone but does not immediately neutralize threat before Randall attacks.
Subdues Randall to protect Boo and declares Randall out of a job, showing protective and caring behavior toward Boo.
Encourages Boo after she makes a playful gesture toward Randall, showing friendliness and encouragement.
Tells Boo to take care of herself and be good, showing sincere care and concern.
Subdues Randall by wrestling him like an alligator, demonstrating physical skill and control.
Confidently tells Randall he is out of a job after Boo is no longer scared, showing clear understanding of the situation.
Prepares and successfully pitches Randall through a door, effectively removing the threat.
Engages cooperatively with Mike to ensure the plan is executed smoothly, showing teamwork and coordination.
Encourages Boo positively after Boo's interaction with Randall, showing social awareness and confidence.
Shows responsibility by reminding Boo to take care of herself and be good before sending her home.
Lifts Boo’s hood gently and apologizes for not noticing it sooner.
Sings playfully to Mike to remind him not to yell in front of Boo, showing care for her feelings.
Encourages Mike and Boo to stay positive and hold on while the door moves uncontrollably.
Noticed Boo's hood was down and lifted it back up to maintain her comfort and secrecy.
Calmly told Mike to not yell in front of Boo, showing awareness of the situation and maintaining morale.
Told Mike to 'Hold on!' when the door suddenly started moving, showing readiness and quick thinking in a sudden situation.
Sneaks out with Boo, protecting her from capture despite danger.
Saves Boo by scooping her up and rushing to escape from authorities.
Pops Boo's door out of its station and heads for the exit while carrying Boo, demonstrating quick thinking and taking initiative to escape with the child.
Knocks over a stack of cans during his escape, creating a distraction but also making noise that could reveal his position.
Races down the hall carrying Boo and her door, successfully evading CDA agents and Waternoose who are in pursuit.
Secures the simulator door with a pipe to keep Waternoose out, rescues Boo by replacing the door to protect her.
Tucks Boo in and reassures her she is safe, speaks to her kindly.
Stands protectively in front of Boo to shield her from Waternoose.
Confronts Waternoose peacefully seeking to avoid violence and protect Boo, tries to reason with him.
Breaks a pipe and uses it to barricade the door handles quickly to prevent Waternoose from entering.
Removes the existing simulator door and replaces it with Boo's door to mislead Waternoose.
Picks up Boo and runs inside the secured room, showing decisiveness and urgency.
Stands protectively in front of Boo when confronted by Waternoose, showing confidence and resolve.
Reacts with an emotional 'No!' and is physically struck and sent flying by Waternoose, showing momentary physical vulnerability.
Scoops Boo up to protect her despite danger.
Expresses desire to send Boo home safely.
Sighs sadly and accepts the painful reality of parting with Boo.
Smiles warmly at Boo, showing encouragement.
Accepts and appreciates toys Boo gives him sincerely.
Hesitates and struggles internally with saying goodbye to Boo.
Playfully flies Boo like an airplane to her bed and tucks her teddy bear in next to her.
Reassures Boo by telling her nothing will come out of the closet to scare her anymore and tickles her chin.
Gives Boo a gentle goodbye, accepts her hug, and looks back at her one last time before leaving.
Calmly and gently tucks Boo into bed, reassures her by saying 'Nothing’s coming out of the closet to scare you anymore,' showing emotional intelligence and care.
Shows sensitivity and responsibility by calmly saying 'Good-bye, Boo,' and handling the farewell moment with care and composure.
Handles the situation with Boo maturely, closing the closet door slowly and thoughtfully, demonstrating deliberate and conscientious behavior.
Shares a silent moment with Mike after the crisis, reflecting on what happened, indicating thoughtful awareness and emotional processing.
Comes to a stop as an idea forms in his mind, showing thoughtful reflection after a major event.
Appears visibly sad and slow to respond to Mike’s upbeat tone after successfully returning Boo and shutting down the factory.
Compliments Mike on filling his quota on the first kid of the day, showing awareness and encouragement.
Dismisses Mike's perfect comedic timing as the main cause of success by sarcastically attributing it to laughter being more powerful than screams.
Smiles fades when seeing Boo’s picture and wooden chip taped to clipboard
Follows Mike despite hesitating, showing willingness to engage
Carefully fits the missing piece into Boo's door and opens it gently, showing consideration and care.
Smiles warmly upon hearing Boo call out and seeing her, indicating friendly and sincere emotions.
Fits the missing piece perfectly into Boo's door, enabling the door to open successfully.
Shows a nervous expression before entering the room but proceeds to open the door carefully.
